importance: This paper is crucial for researchers working with diffusion models because it presents **PFDiff**, a training-free method to significantly speed up sampling.  This is important because generating high-quality samples from diffusion models is computationally expensive. The training-free nature of PFDiff is also a major advantage, as it avoids the cost and complexity of retraining large models. The method is orthogonal to existing ODE solvers, offering a novel approach to accelerate diffusion model sampling that can be easily integrated with many existing diffusion model architectures.
summary: PFDiff: Training-free acceleration of diffusion models using past and future gradient guidance.
takeaways: PFDiff accelerates diffusion model sampling without requiring model retraining.
PFDiff improves sampling quality, particularly when using a small number of function evaluations.
PFDiff is easily adaptable to various existing diffusion model architectures.
tldr:
Diffusion Probabilistic Models (DPMs) are powerful for image generation, but their sampling process is slow due to the numerous denoising steps. Existing solutions mainly focus on accelerating sampling via fast ODE solvers; however, these methods suffer from discretization errors, particularly when using fewer function evaluations (NFE). This is a major limitation because achieving high sampling speed often requires a trade-off with sampling quality.

The paper proposes PFDiff, a novel training-free and orthogonal timestep-skipping strategy. PFDiff leverages the similarity in model outputs at time steps that are not excessively large and utilizes gradient replacement from past time steps and foresight updates inspired by Nesterov momentum to correct discretization errors. Experiments show that PFDiff enhances sampling speed across various pre-trained DPMs, especially excelling in conditional models and surpassing previous training-free methods.  This demonstrates the effectiveness of this new technique for faster and high-quality sample generation.
